description: From bewilder (“to confuse, disorientate, or puzzle someone, especially with many different choices”) +‎ -ing (suffix forming nouns or noun-like words from verbs, denoting the act of doing something, an action, or the embodiment of an action; and forming the present participles of verbs).

adjectives.description: bewildering (comparative more bewildering, superlative most bewildering)

entries.meaning: Very baffling, confusing, or perplexing, often due to a very large choice being available.
examples: Synonyms: dizzying, head-scratching, mind-boggling, puzzlesome; see also Thesaurus:confusing
There was a bewildering collection of curiosities filling the room.
